sentences: Donnie Iris (born Dominic Ierace, February 28, 1943) is an American rock musician known for his work with the Jaggerz and Wild Cherry during the 1970s, and for his solo career beginning in the 1980s with his band, the Cruisers.
section: N/A

sentences: He wrote the #2 Billboard hit, "The Rapper", with the Jaggerz in 1970 and was a member of Wild Cherry after the group had a #1 hit with "Play That Funky Music."
section: N/A

sentences: He also achieved fame as a solo artist in the early 1980s with the #29 hit "Ah!
section: N/A

sentences: Leah!"
section: N/A

sentences: and the #37 hit "Love Is Like a Rock."
section: N/A

sentences: In addition to performing on the first three Jaggerz albums and the fourth and final Wild Cherry album, Iris with his solo band has released eleven studio albums, one EP, two live albums, and two compilation albums.
section: N/A

sentences: He continues to intermittently release new material and tour throughout the greater Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, and Youngstown and Cleveland, Ohio areas.
section: N/A
== Biography ==

sentences: Biography ==
section: == Biography ==
== Biography == | === Early life and early career (1943–63) ===

sentences: Early life and early career (1943–63)
section: == Biography == | === Early life and early career (1943–63) ===
== Biography == | === Early life and early career (1943–63) ===

sentences: Dominic Ierace was born in New Castle, Pennsylvania, but grew up in Ellwood City, Pennsylvania.
section: == Biography == | === Early life and early career (1943–63) ===

sentences: The son of Samuel and Carrie Ierace, young Dominic began to learn how to sing at an early age from his mother, who had sung in Curly Venezie's orchestra.
section: == Biography == | === Early life and early career (1943–63) ===

sentences: He practiced earlier on by singing along with his mother's favorite singers, Frank Sinatra and Tony Bennett.
section: == Biography == | === Early life and early career (1943–63) ===

sentences: Per his mother's encouragement, Ierace began singing at weddings at age five, and by eight was performing on local television and entering talent contests.
section: == Biography == | === Early life and early career (1943–63) ===

sentences: Over time, Ierace began to develop his own interests in music with the advent of rock music, drawing inspiration from Elvis Presley and Buddy Holly and later from the Beatles, the Rolling Stones and even R&B and soul artists Marvin Gaye and Ray Charles in addition to other Motown acts.
section: == Biography == | === Early life and early career (1943–63) ===

sentences: The popularity of rock and roll inspired Ierace to become a self-taught guitarist.
section: == Biography == | === Early life and early career (1943–63) ===

sentences: When his voice changed around age 12, he gave up singing and took up the drums.
section: == Biography == | === Early life and early career (1943–63) ===

sentences: About the time he was a senior in high school (circa 1961), Ierace's voice changed again, and he got back into singing.
section: == Biography == | === Early life and early career (1943–63) ===

sentences: He formed a vocal doo-wop group called the Fabutons with Johnny Roth, Anthony Matteo, Lou Delessandro and Chuckie Hasson and performed gigs around Beaver and Lawrence counties in Pennsylvania.
section: == Biography == | === Early life and early career (1943–63) ===

sentences: However, the group only performed a few times before they disbanded and Ierace went to college.
section: == Biography == | === Early life and early career (1943–63) ===

sentences: While attending Slippery Rock State College, Ierace formed a band called the Tri-Vels with guitarist Jim Evans and drummer Dave Amodie, two fellow students at Slippery Rock.
section: == Biography == | === Early life and early career (1943–63) ===

sentences: With the addition of bassist Dave Reiser, they renamed themselves Donnie and the Donnells.
section: == Biography == | === Early life and early career (1943–63) ===

sentences: This band in both incarnations played R&B and pop rock covers at fraternity parties and lasted from about 1961 to 1964.
section: == Biography == | === Early life and early career (1943–63) ===
== Biography == | === The Jaggerz and Wild Cherry (1964–79) ===

sentences: The Jaggerz and Wild Cherry (1964–79) ===
section: == Biography == | === The Jaggerz and Wild Cherry (1964–79) ===

sentences: Around 1964, Ierace left Donnie and the Donnells to form the Jaggerz (originally the "Jaggers") with Benny Faiella of Gary and the Jewel Tones.
section: == Biography == | === The Jaggerz and Wild Cherry (1964–79) ===

sentences: After a few changes in line-up early on (including acquiring Jimmie Ross and Jim Pugliano from the Bell Boys), the group became popular playing R&B covers throughout western Pennsylvania and northeastern Ohio.
section: == Biography == | === The Jaggerz and Wild Cherry (1964–79) ===

sentences: Eventually, Ierace and the Jaggerz began to write their own material and secured a contract with Gamble Records.
section: == Biography == | === The Jaggerz and Wild Cherry (1964–79) ===

sentences: Their first album, Introducing the Jaggerz, was released in 1969.
section: == Biography == | === The Jaggerz and Wild Cherry (1964–79) ===

sentences: The album was only a minor success, mainly receiving airplay in Iris' native Beaver County and the rest of the greater Pittsburgh area.
section: == Biography == | === The Jaggerz and Wild Cherry (1964–79) ===

sentences: Perhaps most importantly, it was the first album Ierace recorded on.
section: == Biography == | === The Jaggerz and Wild Cherry (1964–79) ===

sentences: Ierace and the Jaggerz first came to national prominence in 1970 for the #2 hit "The Rapper," written by Ierace and included on their second album, We Went to Different Schools Together, released on the Kama Sutra label.
section: == Biography == | === The Jaggerz and Wild Cherry (1964–79) ===

sentences: The album itself reached #69 on the charts.
section: == Biography == | === The Jaggerz and Wild Cherry (1964–79) ===

sentences: The Jaggerz would go on to release one more album, Come Again, in 1975 when they were signed with Wooden Nickel Records.
section: == Biography == | === The Jaggerz and Wild Cherry (1964–79) ===

sentences: However, it failed to produce any more hits for the group.
section: == Biography == | === The Jaggerz and Wild Cherry (1964–79) ===

sentences: Between 1975 and 1976, most of the Jaggerz' longtime members left the group, including Ierace in 1976.
section: == Biography == | === The Jaggerz and Wild Cherry (1964–79) ===

sentences: The Jaggerz eventually broke up around 1977, but reunited in 1989 without Ierace, who by that point was well into his solo career.
section: == Biography == | === The Jaggerz and Wild Cherry (1964–79) ===

sentences: After his departure from the Jaggerz, Ierace began to learn engineering at Jeree Recording in New Brighton, Pennsylvania.
section: == Biography == | === The Jaggerz and Wild Cherry (1964–79) ===

sentences: Also, he did about a two-year stint (1976-1978) playing shows with B. E. Taylor.
section: == Biography == | === The Jaggerz and Wild Cherry (1964–79) ===

sentences: While working at Jeree, the band Wild Cherry (a hot commodity because of their 1976 hit "Play That Funky Music," which had been recorded there), was booked for a recording session.
section: == Biography == | === The Jaggerz and Wild Cherry (1964–79) ===

sentences: Ierace helped to engineer their third album, I Love My Music.
section: == Biography == | === The Jaggerz and Wild Cherry (1964–79) ===

sentences: The band was also looking for a new guitarist, and upon learning of Ierace and his association with "The Rapper," he was recruited by frontman Rob Parissi.
section: == Biography == | === The Jaggerz and Wild Cherry (1964–79) ===

sentences: Ierace went on the road with the group for about the next year and was featured on their 1979 album Only the Wild Survive.
section: == Biography == | === The Jaggerz and Wild Cherry (1964–79) ===

sentences: Throughout the 1970s, Ierace was credited by various names on Jaggerz and Wild Cherry albums: by his birth name, Dominic Ierace; Don Ierace; and a stage name he had adopted to make it easier for people to remember his name, Don Iris.
section: == Biography == | === The Jaggerz and Wild Cherry (1964–79) ===

sentences: By the end of the decade, as far as his music/public life went, he went by the name of Donnie Iris.
section: == Biography == | === The Jaggerz and Wild Cherry (1964–79) ===

sentences: It was during this period that he became acquainted with Mark Avsec, then playing keyboards for Wild Cherry.
section: == Biography == | === The Jaggerz and Wild Cherry (1964–79) ===

sentences: Wild Cherry was unable to duplicate the success of "Play That Funky Music" and disbanded by the end of the decade.
section: == Biography == | === The Jaggerz and Wild Cherry (1964–79) ===

sentences: Becoming good friends, Donnie and Mark decided to form a project together after Wild Cherry's breakup and the two began writing songs.
section: == Biography == | === The Jaggerz and Wild Cherry (1964–79) ===

sentences: Their first release saw the disco-influenced single "Bring on the Eighties" backed by a cover of "Because of You" in 1979; however it failed to garner attention.
section: == Biography == | === The Jaggerz and Wild Cherry (1964–79) ===

sentences: Iris and Avsec decided to go in a harder direction for their next release and returned to the studio with guitarist Marty Lee Hoenes, bassist Albritton McClain and drummer Kevin Valentine, who at the time was in the band Breathless with Avsec, to record his first full-length album.
section: == Biography == | === The Jaggerz and Wild Cherry (1964–79) ===

sentences: This line-up would form to what would become known as Donnie Iris and the Cruisers.
section: == Biography == | === The Jaggerz and Wild Cherry (1964–79) ===

sentences: Leah!" peaked at #29 on the Billboard Hot 100 (and #34 in Australia) in February 1981 and became one of the most frequently played AOR tracks of the year, and the album reached #57 on the Billboard 200.

sentences: In addition, the band launched a national tour to promote the album and its follow-up during the summer of 1981.

sentences: The follow-up album, King Cool, credited to Donnie Iris and the Cruisers, was released in August 1981 and garnered the band more AOR success, with "Love Is Like a Rock" reaching #9 on Billboard's Top Tracks chart.
section: == Biography == | === Donnie Iris and the Cruisers' peak years (1980–85) ===

sentences: Two other songs from the album received significant AOR airplay; "My Girl" at #25 and "Sweet Merilee" at #31, charted on the Rock Tracks chart.

sentences: In addition, he gained the nickname King Cool  from this album in the later part of his career.

sentences: However, the album itself charted less successfully, at #84.
section: == Biography == | === Donnie Iris and the Cruisers' peak years (1980–85) ===

sentences: After the long tour promoting their two previous albums, the band continued songwriting and in the fall of 1982 released The High and the Mighty.
section: == Biography == | === Donnie Iris and the Cruisers' peak years (1980–85) ===

sentences: The album contained the single "Tough World," but only charted at #180, marking a decline in his success, but the band still was determined to release new material.
section: == Biography == | === Donnie Iris and the Cruisers' peak years (1980–85) ===

sentences: Their next album one year later, Fortune 410, contained the hit single "Do You Compute?" which was used by their label MCA and the computer company Atari to form a cross-marketing promotion.
section: == Biography == | === Donnie Iris and the Cruisers' peak years (1980–85) ===

sentences: Because the promotional partnership was secured prior to release of the album, it was possible to use the Atari 1200 XL Home Computer in poster photography, as well as in the video clip for "Do You Compute?", which aired on MTV.

sentences: The title of the album is a reference to the trademark glasses Iris wears, Fortune 410's.

sentences: The combination of marketing and the promotion for its hit single allowed the album to chart higher than its predecessor.
section: == Biography == | === Donnie Iris and the Cruisers' peak years (1980–85) ===

sentences: Despite Fortune 410 charting higher than The High and the Mighty, MCA was displeased that both albums didn't chart as high as Back on the Streets and King Cool had.
section: == Biography == | === Donnie Iris and the Cruisers' peak years (1980–85) ===

sentences: The label suggested that the band allow them to bring in a new producer, displacing Mark Avsec, as well bring in new songwriters.
section: == Biography == | === Donnie Iris and the Cruisers' peak years (1980–85) ===

sentences: Iris and the Cruisers, wanting to keep as much of their creative freedom and sound as they could, said no.

sentences: As a result, MCA dropped the band in 1984.

sentences: Shortly after being let go from MCA, the band signed with the small HME Records label.

sentences: Their next album, No Muss...No Fuss, released in 1985, continued the trend set by Fortune 410 by charting at #115 with the single "Injured in the Game of Love".

sentences: Both of the aforementioned albums ended up being more critically acclaimed than The High and the Mighty.
